chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: In this problem, we will determine the net present value of an investment.

**Net present value** is a method used to determine, if an investment is acceptable or not. It represents the difference between the present value of future cash flows that we expect to receive from investment and invested amount of money (investment cost).

In order to understand the net present value definition, we should understand the concept of **time value of money**. According to it, the value of money received today is greater than the value of the same amount of money received in the future. The reason for this lies in the ability to earn a return if we invest the money today.

Let's get back to our net present value definition and explain it further. Imagine that you bought a machine. The amount of money that you paid for it represents investment cost (invested amount). Then, let's imagine that you will use the machine, produce products, sell them to the customers and receive corresponding cash flows.

Now, **due to the time value of money, invested amount and, future cash flows that you expect to receive can not be compared** since they come from different time periods. Therefore, it is necessary to determine the present value of every expected future cash flow.

In the end, it is necessary to compare the sum of all present values of cash flows with the invested amount of money (by subtracting them). **If the sum of all present values is greater than invested value, the investment should be accepted** since it adds value to you. In such a case what you get from an investment is greater than the invested amount. Otherwise, investment should be rejected.

Now, we can write the net present value (NPV) formula: 

$$\begin{aligned} \text{NPV}&=\text{PV}-\text{I}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Also, we can write formula for calculation of present value of expected future cash flows (PV):


$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}&=\frac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\frac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+...+\frac{\text{CF}_\text{t}}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^\text{t}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Where:



I = Investment Cost (Invested Amount)\
$\text{CF}_\text{i}$ = Expected Future Cash Flows from Period i\
R = Discount Rate\
t = Number of Time Periods

Let's identify the given inputs:

|Variable |$\hspace{15pt}$ Value | 
|--|--| 
| Investment Cost|$\hspace{10pt}$-$15,400|
|Cash Flow from Year 1| $\hspace{13pt}$ $7,300| 
|Cash Flow from Year 2 | $\hspace{14pt}$ $9,100| 
|Cash Flow from Year 3 |  $\hspace{13pt}$                                  $5,900 | 
|Discount Rates|0%, 20% and 30%|

**a) Net present value for the discount rate of zero percent**

Next, we can determine the net present value for the discount rate of zero percent.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{NPV}&=\frac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\frac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+\frac{\text{CF}_3}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^3}-\text{I}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{7,300}{\left(1+0\right)^1}+\frac{9,100}{\left(1+0\right)^2}+\frac{5,900}{\left(1+0\right)^3}-\text{15,400}\\[15pt]
&=7,300+9,100+5,900-15,400\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf\$6,900}
\end{aligned}$$
**The net present value of a project is $6,900 at a discount rate of zero percent. We should invest in such a project since the net present value is the positive. Positive net present value of a project leads to the creation of additional value.**

**b) Net present value for the discount rate of 10 percent**

Now, let's calculate the net present value for the discount rate of 10 percent.
$$\begin{aligned} \text{NPV}&=\frac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\frac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+\frac{\text{CF}_3}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^3}-\text{I}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{7,300}{\left(1+0.1\right)^1}+\frac{9,100}{\left(1+0.1\right)^2}+\frac{5,900}{\left(1+0.1\right)^3}-\text{15,400}\\[15pt]
&=6,636.36+7,520.66+4,432.76-15,400\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf\$3,189.78}
\end{aligned}$$
**The net present value of such project is a $3,189.78 at a discount rate of 10 percent. The net present value is positive and the project can be undertaken.**

**c) Net present value for the discount rate of 20 percent**

We will continue with the calculation of the net present value for the discount rate of 20 percent.
$$\begin{aligned} \text{NPV}&=\frac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\frac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+\frac{\text{CF}_3}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^3}-\text{I}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{7,300}{\left(1+0.2\right)^1}+\frac{9,100}{\left(1+0.2\right)^2}+\frac{5,900}{\left(1+0.2\right)^3}-\text{15,400}\\[15pt]
&=6,083.33+6,319.44+3,414.35-15,400\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf\$417.13}
\end{aligned}$$

**In the case of a discount rate of 20 percent, the net present value is $417.13. The project should be undertaken since it creates additional value for the company.**

**d) Net present value for the discount rate of 30 percent**

At the end, we will determine the net present value for the discount rate of 30 percent.
$$\begin{aligned} \text{NPV}&=\frac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\frac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+\frac{\text{CF}_3}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^3}-\text{I}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{7,300}{\left(1+0.3\right)^1}+\frac{9,100}{\left(1+0.3\right)^2}+\frac{5,900}{\left(1+0.3\right)^3}-\text{15,400}\\[15pt]
&=5,615.38+5,384.62+2,685.48-15,400\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf-\$1,714.52}
\end{aligned}$$  

**The net present value of the project is -$1,714.52 if a discount rate is 30 percent. The project has a negative net present value and it shouldn't be undertaken.**

**To conclude, the net present value of the project with the discount rate of:**
- **0 percent is $6,900.00**
- **10 percent is $3,189.78** 
- **20 percent is $417.13** 
- **30 percent is -$1,714.52.**
